title: Lesson 1: Basic Greetings
content:
Lesson 1: Basic Greetings # Benvenuto! In this first lesson, weâ€™ll dive into some basic Italian greetings. Knowing how to greet people is the first step to sounding friendly (and maybe even a little Italian). So, letâ€™s get started!
1. Saying â€œHelloâ€ â€“ The Classic Ciao! # The most versatile Italian greeting is Ciao!. You can say this when you meet someone and when youâ€™re leaving â€“ itâ€™s the Italian way of saying both â€œHelloâ€ and â€œGoodbye.â€
Example: You: Ciao! Italian Friend: Ciao! Note: â€œCiaoâ€ is informal. Use it with friends, family, and people youâ€™re comfortable with. If you say it to your boss, though, expect a raised eyebrow.
2. â€œGood Morningâ€ and â€œGood Afternoonâ€ # If you want to sound a bit more formal, use these greetings:
Buongiorno â€“ Good morning (used until about 2 PM)
Buon pomeriggio â€“ Good afternoon (used in the afternoon but not very common; â€œBuongiornoâ€ can cover this too)
Example:
You: Buongiorno! Barista: Buongiorno! Un caffÃ¨? 3. â€œGood Eveningâ€ and â€œGood Nightâ€ # For later in the day, Italians use different greetings:
Buonasera â€“ Good evening (from around 5 PM onwards)

Why Do We Use ‘ho’ and ‘sono’ in the Past Tense? # Learning Italian grammar can feel like cooking pasta al dente: a bit of pressure, but worth it! If youâ€™re wondering why Italians switch between “ho” and “sono” in the past tense, letâ€™s dive in (without overcooking it).
In Italian, “ho” (from avere) and “sono” (from essere) are like your grammar sidekicks. They help form the past tense (passato prossimo) in ways that even native speakers might shrug about. Hereâ€™s the scoop:
1. Transitive vs. Intransitive Verbs # Transitive verbs (verbs that take a direct object) go with avere (ho, hai, ha, etc.). Itâ€™s like theyâ€™re ready to pass something around â€“ usually an object!
Example:
Ho mangiato la pizza. â€“ I ate the pizza.
Here, mangiato directly affects pizza, and letâ€™s face it, who wouldnâ€™t be affected by pizza? ğŸ•
Intransitive verbs (verbs without a direct object) are often loners and prefer essere (sono, sei, Ã¨, etc.), as they donâ€™t need a buddy (aka, a direct object).
Example:
Sono uscito. â€“ I went out.
Uscire (to go out) is a free spirit, so it uses essere to keep things moving along.
2. Movement, Change of State, and Reflexive Verbs # Essere steps in when thereâ€™s action, transformation, or a little self-reflection (yes, Italian grammar is deep like that).
Movement verbs (think andare â€“ to go, venire â€“ to come, uscire â€“ to go out). If thereâ€™s a journey involved, youâ€™re with essere.
Example:
Sono andato a casa. â€“ I went home.
Just me, going home â€“ not taking anything or anyone with me. Simple! Change of state verbs (like nascere â€“ to be born, morire â€“ to die, diventare â€“ to become). If thereâ€™s transformation, essere takes the stage.
Example:
Ãˆ nato ieri. â€“ He was born yesterday.
Quite a change of state â€“ from nothing to a full human! Reflexive verbs (verbs where the action turns back on the subject, like svegliarsi â€“ to wake up). Think of these as verbs that like to look in the mirror.
Example:
Mi sono svegliato tardi. â€“ I woke up late.
Yep, essere is here too, helping with our late (and often reluctant) start to the day. â˜•ï¸ 3. Gender and Number Agreement with Essere # Hereâ€™s where essere really shows its Italian flair: the past participle agrees in gender and number with the subject. So, be ready to match!
Examples:
Sono andato (masculine singular) vs. Sono andata (feminine singular) Siamo andati (masculine plural) vs. Siamo andate (feminine plural) With avere, though, the past participle doesnâ€™t worry about matching anyoneâ€™s gender or number. Itâ€™s easygoing like that.
Example:
Ho mangiato (I ate) â€“ same form whether youâ€™re male or female, young or old. A real crowd-pleaser.
Quick Summary # Avere (ho, hai, ha, etc.) is used for most verbs with direct objects â€“ the ones that affect something else.
Example: Ho letto un libro. â€“ I read a book.
Essere (sono, sei, Ã¨, etc.) is for verbs of movement, change of state, and reflexive verbs â€“ think travel, transformation, or talking to yourself.
Example: Sono arrivato/a. â€“ I arrived.
